creator: TechShop Grandma
title: Positioning Vinyl Lettering: Getting it Straight - I made it at the TechShop
materials_required: Vinyl letters (cut and weeded with transfer paper applied)
description: This project describes how to accurately position vinyl lettering on a surface to create a sign, ensuring the letters are straight and properly aligned. It addresses the common issue of letters going uphill and provides a step-by-step guide for a successful application.
steps: Prepare the board or surface where the letters will be applied.
Trim the letter layer (vinyl letters with transfer paper) close to the lettering.
Position the letter layer on the board.
Cut paper strips for side margins and attach them to the board using glue stick. Mark the top margin position on these strips.
Secure the letter layer to the board with masking tape, creating a hinge along the top edge.
Flip the letter layer up, exposing the backing paper, and carefully peel it off.
Slowly roll the letter layer onto the board, using a yardstick to smooth the letters and prevent gaps or wrinkles.
Burnish the letters through the transfer paper to ensure they adhere firmly to the board.
Add color by hand with artist's acrylic paint (optional).
Seal the entire sign with several coats of clear finish (optional).
